Mark Farrell

Closed Walks and Cospectral Graphs

Oct 24, 2016

In this post, my goal is to verify that a pair of simple graphs are cospectral if and only if their respective generating series for all closed walks weighted by length are equal.

Suppose that is a simple graph with adjacency matrix . Then, first and foremost, I would like to give a couple of definitions in this context:

  1. The generating series closed walks on weighted by length is given by - assuming, for the purposes of this post, the fact that gives the total number of closed walks of length on for all .

Note that here , i.e. it is an element of the algebra of formal power series with real coefficients.

  1. Suppose that the characteristic polynomial of the adjacency matrix of is given by . Additionally, suppose that is another simple graph where the characteristic polynomial of the adjacency matrix of is given by . Then and are said to be cospectral if .

Now, in order to achieve my original goal for this post of verifying that a pair of simple graphs are cospectral if and only if their respective generating series for all closed walks weighted by length are equal, I would first like to necessarily propose that the following facts hold in this context:

  1. Suppose that minimal polynomial of the adjacency matrix of is given by . Additionally, suppose that has the spectral decomposition , where is the set whose elements consist of all of the roots of . Then the generating series for all closed walks on weighted by length admits the partial fraction decomposition .

  2. If the adjacency matrix of has the spectral decomposition , where is the set whose elements consist of the distinct eigenvalues of , then gives the multiplicity of as an eigenvalue of for all .

Assuming that these facts hold in this context, then it is possible to then further deduce that the generating series for all closed walks on weighted by length admits a closed form as a rational expression involving the characteristic polynomial of the adjacency matrix of and its formal derivative relative to a certain formal symbol in context, which will be useful for achieving my original goal of verifying that a pair of simple graphs are cospectral if and only if their respective generating series for all closed walks weighted by length are equal:

  1. Suppose that the closed walk generating series of all closed walks on weighted by length admits the partial fraction decomposition , where is the set whose elements consist of distinct eigenvalues of and each denotes the multiplicity of as an eigenvalue of for all . Additionally, suppose that the characteristic polynomial of is given by . Then, we can further deduce from here that:

Note that here denotes another formal symbol that happens to have the relation with the formal symbol and should not be interpreted as a “function of ” in the sense of calculus when e.g. considering the formal derivative of with respect to the formal symbol in context.

I would now like to show that the previous two facts that I assumed to be true indeed hold in this context:

  1. Consider the left-shift operator acting on the algebra of formal power series with real coefficients, defined as for all ; I would like to assume, for the purposes of this post, that this operator is indeed linear and that can be interpreted as a vector space. Then, core linear algebra tells us that given the minimal polynomial of the adjacency matrix of , admits the direct sum decomposition ; I would also ask, for the purposes of this blog post, that you believe me that this fact from linear algebra is indeed true - and also the fact that a formal power series is an eigenvector for an eigenvalue of if and only if is a (non-zero) scalar multiple of . Now, from linearity properties of the trace map where denotes the number of vertices on in this context, we can deduce that ; hence we can deduce that for some unique scalars for all . However, if we know that the adjacency matrix of has the spectral decomposition where denotes the set of distinct eigenvalues of , then it turns out that has the spectral decomposition for all ; and hence it turns out that for all by linearity properties of trace. If we consider the fact that the -th coefficient of is given by and is also given by the -th coefficient of which is equal to for all , then we see that each for all since each is unique. Hence we ultimately get that admits the partial fraction decomposition as desired.

  2. Consider the spectral idempotent for an arbitrary where denotes the set of distinct eigenvalues of the adjacency matrix of . Then, since we can see that and hence that the minimal polynomial of of is given by ; since splits into distinct linear factors, this means that is diagonalizable with s and s lying along the diagonal matrix that it is similar to. Since the rank of the diagonal matrix that is similar to is equal to the rank of , and since the only non-zero entries in the diagonal matrix that is similar to will be s lying along said matrix’s diagonal, we can deduce that . Lastly, since , and since the multiplicity of as a eigenvalue of the adjacency matrix of is given by , we get that . Therefore we get that for all , since our choice of in this context is arbitrary.

Now, I would like to break out of this context here and conclude that in general the closed walk generating series admits a closed form as a rational expression in the sense that I’ve shown is true in this context, since in this context is arbitrary. I would next like to move onward to achieving my original goal of verifying that a pair of simple graphs are cospectral if and only if their respective generating series for all closed walks weighted by length are equal:

  1. Suppose that and are a pair of cospectral simple graphs, where the respective characteristic polynomials of the adjacency matrices of and are denoted by and . Then, assuming that my previous result is true, we can see that the respective generating series and for all closed walks on and weighted by length admit closed forms as rational expressions given by and . However, since and are cospectral, we know that in particular and can further deduce that as well. Hence, it is quite clear that in this context; therefore, if any pair simple graphs of are cospectral, then their respective generating series for all closed walks weighted by length must be equal, since and in this context are arbitrary.

  2. Now, suppose that and are a pair of simple graphs whose respective generating series for all closed walks weighted by length are equal, i.e . Then, assuming my previous result, we know that where and denote the respective characteristic polynomials of the adjacency matrices of and . From this, we can ultimately deduce that and furthermore that . Lastly, since characteristic polynomials are monic, we can then deduce that from the fact that . Hence we get that and can see that . Therefore, we can conclude that and are cospectral because their respective characteristic polynomials are equal; we can also more generally conclude that if the respective generating series for closed walks weighted by length of a pair of simple graphs are equal, then they must be cospectral, since and in this context are arbitrary.

Therefore, we can ultimately conclude from this post that a pair of simple graphs are cospectral if and only if their respective generating series for all closed walks weighted by length are equal, as desired.
